author: sproul
content:
As a CL dev and author of one EIP (https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-3076) I found the process quite heavy-weight, and constrained by odd restrictions compared to `consensus-specs`. I agree that having input from a wide range of stakeholders is important though. At risk of bike-shedding I would be down to talk about reducing friction in the EIP process.

Concrete examples of things that frustrated me:

- I wasn't able to include test cases as an artefact alongside the EIP, they needed to be in a separate repo or inlined in the text (very impractical). As a result, my EIP doesn't even link to the test cases, they just got passed around out-of-band.
- The emphasis on writing in a "timeless" manner is frustrating for an evolving technology. I had to remove any reference to any extant client or implementation because these were considering too liable to bitrot (concept rot?).

I know that <@554799849288105986> shared some of these frustrations too when he wrote an EIP. Maybe part of this friction is innate to writing better specs, and we should just grit our teeth and bear it?

I saw the recent call for EIP editors from the CL side, and while I appreciate that, I wouldn't really want to volunteer as an editor myself because I've got enough going on and the EIP process is pretty peripheral to most of the work I do. If it were more integral (i.e. the CL had a culture of using EIPs) then I can imagine that position being more appealing.

author: ethdreamer
content:
Yeah I spent a very long time on my EIP polishing it as best I could. I think it's maybe fair to say that my EIP is in the top 5 *most standard conformant* EIPs that have been written (all sections included, pythonic reference implementation, test cases that the implementation passes, etc.) and despite all that effort, I still had to deal with quite a lot to get my most recent PR through.

And that was with the support of other prominent devs and editors going to bat for me (lightclients, Pooja, etc.).

Granted the incident did lead to a policy change and was kind of a flashpoint that the process needs improvement.

From my experience, the issue was that you needed basically unanimous support from the editors. So even one or two people with reservations can be enough to significantly slow down or stop the process.
